messageBody:
to find the reason for failure and to see where it
failed and why, don't you think a good debugging ide
like jbuilder, eclipse ot net beans would be a good
idea.

--- Vladimir Ritz Bossicard <vladimir@...>
wrote:
> > What about http://apricot.sourceforge.net/ ?
>
> Good catch. The project is quite dead but if you're
> interested in the
> idea behind it, you can have a look at JUnit-addons
> Runner. Same idea,
> simpler implementation.
>
> > "During their execution, the classes have access
> to
> > external ressources (database or network
> connections...)
> > via Services and can use the Logger to save useful
> information."
> >
> > Vladamir, are you saying you don't need such a
> Logger any more?
>
> Never say 'never' but I never had to use a logger
> for my tests. So far.
> But if I have to, I want to have this option open.
>
> My experience with System.out is that you don't
> write them when you are
> writing your tests, but only when something goes
> wrong. If your test
> for 'Object myfunction()' is:
>
> Integer actual = myClass.myfunction();
> assertEquals(new Integer(3), actual);
>
> and it fails with a ClassCastException (typically
> you don't know much
> about what really happens), you will be tempted to
> put a System.out to
> see what was returned:
>
> System.out.println("returned class : " +
> actual.getClass());
>
> IMO this smells because you will have to look at the
> result (output,
> log) and after writing a few hundreds of these
> statements your console
> (or log) will be flooded with unuseful output
> (because you have now
> information about something that works).
>
> What I do instead is use the JUnit-addons library
> (of course, since I
> wrote it!) and write:
>
> ObjectAssert.assertInstanceOf(Integer.class,
> actual);
>
> 1) if it fails, I will get the message "expected of
> class <Integer> but
> was of class <Boolean>": Exactly the same
> information as with a
> System.out BUT...
>
> 2) if it doesn't fail, I will not get any output
>
> > How do people fix such a failing test? What
> information do you use to
> > diagnose and fix it? Or is it always the time to
> reach for your
> > debugger?
>
> I hope that I explained how I fix failing tests: I
> try to grab as much
> information as possible but without writing anything
> on the console/log.
>
> And how can a logger be useful: typically to record
> the environment
> where the tests were executed (name of the server,
> database, what is the
> locale, ...) and not how they were executed. But I
> may change my mind
> on this.
>
> -Vladimir
>
